/wiki/ICAO_airport_code: The ICAO (/ˌaɪˌkeɪˈoʊ/, eye-KAY-oh) airport code or location indicator is a four-letter code designating aerodromes around the world. These codes, as defined by the International Civil Aviation Organization and published in ICAO Document 7910: Location Indicators, are used by air traffic control and airline operations such as flight planning.
/wiki/Bobete: Bobete is a community council located in the Thaba-Tseka District of Lesotho. Its population in 2006 was 12,966.
/wiki/Bobete_Airport: Bobete Airport (ICAO: FXBB) is an airport serving Bobete, a village in the Thaba-Tseka District of Lesotho.
/wiki/Katse_Dam: The Katse Dam, a concrete arch dam on the Malibamat'so River in Lesotho, is Africa's second largest double-curvature arch dam.  (The Tekezé Dam, completed in early 2009, is now Africa's largest double curvature dam).  The dam is part of the Lesotho Highlands Water Project, which will eventually include five large dams in remote rural areas. The dam is just below the confluence of the Bokong River, which forms the western arm of the Katse reservoir.
/wiki/Katse_Airport: Katse Airport (ICAO: FXKA) is an airport serving the  Katse Dam section of the Lesotho Highlands Water Project in north-central Lesotho.
/wiki/Kuebunyane_Airport: Kuebunyane Airport (ICAO: FXKY) is an airstrip serving the Basotho villages of Kuebunyane in Mohale's Hoek District, Lesotho.
/wiki/Lebakeng_Airport: Lebakeng Airport (IATA: LEF, ICAO: FXLK) is an airport serving the settlement of Lebakeng, Lesotho.
/wiki/Hlotse: Hlotse (also Leribe) is an important market town in Lesotho. It is situated on the Hlotse River, near the South African border. The town was founded in 1876 by a British missionary, Reverend John Widdicombe. It was a colonial centre until Lesotho gained its independence. The population in 2016 was 38,558.
/wiki/Leribe_Airport: Leribe Airport (IATA: LRB, ICAO: FXLR) is an airport serving Hlotse, the camptown (capital) of the Leribe District of Lesotho.
/wiki/Lesobeng: Lesobeng is a community council located in the Thaba-Tseka District of Lesotho. Its population in 2006 was 12,542.
/wiki/Lesobeng_Airport: Lesobeng Airport (IATA: LES, ICAO: FXLS) is an airstrip serving the community of Lesobeng, in the Thaba-Tseka District of Lesotho.
/wiki/Kolberg_Airport: Kolberg Airport (ICAO: FXKB) is an airstrip serving the village of Letlapeng in the Thaba-Tseka District of Lesotho.
/wiki/Letseng_diamond_mine: The Letšeng diamond mine, found in the landlocked Southern African kingdom of Lesotho, is owned by Gem Diamonds, Ltd. and the government of Lesotho, and at an elevation of 3,100 m (10,000 ft) it is the world's highest diamond mine.
/wiki/Letseng_Airport: Letseng Airport (ICAO: FXLT) is an airstrip serving the Letseng diamond mine in Mokhotlong District, Lesotho. The runway is at very high elevation, 10,084.8 feet.
/wiki/Mafeteng: Mafeteng is a city in Lesotho, and the Camptown (capital city) of the district of Mafeteng. It is located about 76 kilometres south of the country's capital, Maseru and has a population of approximately 61,000. The South African border town to Mafeteng is Wepener.
/wiki/Mafeteng_Airport: Mafeteng Airport (IATA: MFC, ICAO: FXMF) is an airport serving the city of Mafeteng, the capital of Mafeteng District, Lesotho.
/wiki/Malefiloane_Airstrip: Malefiloane Airstrip (ICAO: FXML) is a high elevation airstrip serving the village of Malefiloane in Mokhotlong District, Lesotho. The runway is on a ridge above the Mokhotlong River valley.
/wiki/Matekane_Air_Strip: Matekane Air Strip is a high elevation airstrip serving Matekane, Lesotho, with a runway that extends to the edge of a 500 m (1,600 ft) cliff. The runway is often used by charity organizations and doctors to access remote villages in the area, and is known as one of the world's scariest runways.
/wiki/Mantsonyane: Mantsonyane is a town in central Lesotho. It is located southeast of the capital Maseru, close to the western approach to the Mokhoabong Pass, on a high mountain plateau between the towns of Marakabei and Thaba-Tseka, in the Thaba-Tseka District.
/wiki/Mantsonyane_Airport: Mantsonyane Airport (ICAO: FXMN) is an airport serving the town of Mantsonyane in Thaba-Tseka District, Lesotho.
/wiki/Matabeng_Store_Airstrip: Matabeng Store Airstrip (ICAO: FXMT) is an airstrip serving the village of Matabeng in Qacha's Nek District, Lesotho.
/wiki/Matsaile_Airport: Matsaile Airport (IATA: MSG, ICAO: FXMA) is an airport serving the village of  Matsaile in Thaba-Tseka District, Lesotho.
/wiki/Mohale's_Hoek: Mohale's Hoek is the capital city of Mohale's Hoek District in Lesotho. It had a population of approximately 40,040 in 2016.
/wiki/Mohale's_Hoek_Airport: Mohale's Hoek Airport (ICAO: FXMH) is an airport serving the city of Mohale's Hoek, the capital of Mohale's Hoek District, Lesotho.
/wiki/Mohlanapeng: Mohlanapeng is a community council located in the Thaba-Tseka District of Lesotho. Its population in 2006 was 9,882.
/wiki/Mohlanapeng_Airport: Mohlanapeng Airstrip (ICAO: FXMP) is an airstrip serving the Mohlanapeng community in Thaba-Tseka District, Lesotho.
/wiki/Mokhotlong: Mokhotlong is a city and seat of Mokhotlong District in the mountainous northeastern part of Lesotho. It is the first major city with an airport along the road from South Africa across the Sani Pass, near the Maloti (Drakensberg in South Africa) Mountains. The name of the city is a word in Sesotho, the language of the people of Lesotho, meaning "Place of the Bald Ibis." Thabana Ntlenyana, the highest point in southern Africa is found in Mokhotlong.
/wiki/Mokhotlong_Airport: Mokhotlong Airport (IATA: MKH, ICAO: FXMK) is an airport serving Mokhotlong, the camptown of Mokhotlong District, Lesotho.
/wiki/Maseru: Maseru is the capital and largest city of Lesotho. It is also the capital of the Maseru District. Located on the Caledon River, Maseru lies directly on the Lesotho-South Africa border. Maseru had a population of 330,760 in the 2016 census. The city was established as a police camp and assigned as the capital after the country became a British protectorate in 1869. When the country achieved independence in 1966, Maseru retained its status as capital. The name of the city is a Sesotho word meaning "red sandstones".
/wiki/Moshoeshoe_I_International_Airport: Moshoeshoe I International Airport (IATA: MSU, ICAO: FXMM) is an airport serving Maseru, the capital city of Lesotho.  The airport is named in honor of Moshoeshoe I, king of Lesotho in the 1850s. It is in the town of Mazenod, 18 km (11 mi) southeast of downtown Maseru.
/wiki/Mejametalana_Airport: Mejametalana Airport (ICAO: FXMU) is a military airport in Maseru, the capital city of Lesotho. It served as Maseru's main airport until the opening of Moshoeshoe I International Airport, located in the town of Mazenod, about 18 km (11 mi) southeast of downtown Maseru.
/wiki/Nkaus_Airport: Nkaus Airport (IATA: NKU, ICAO: FXNK) is an airport serving the village of Nkaus, Lesotho.
/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Lesotho: List of airports in Lesotho, sorted by location.
